bibl.subject: Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory (1805-1809)

div.p: 1. I walk’d to Cambridge this Morning, with John Smith, and read my 15th: lecture— Went into the library, and finished the perusal of Leland’s Dissertation upon Eloquence.— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and at 2. O’Clock attended the Declamation— There were only five Speakers; and the attendance from the two Senior Classes was very thin— I walk’d home from Cambridge, and did not go out in the Evening.

2. My brother came into Boston this morning from Dedham, and returned with Mrs: Adams to Quincy— She has been spending the week in the Town, at her Sister’s— Mr: Boylston brought us a present from his house, but could not stay in town to dine with us— My brother did— This afternoon I went out with George to Quincy in the Stage— Mr: Blackburn was in company with us.

3. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— In the afternoon I went up to my place, and saw my new Tenants— Heard great complaints of Cattle breaking in, and the like— Briesler defeated my purpose of making a distribution of my lands between two tenants, and the consequence is that it must again almost all go to one— I was employed all the remainder of the day, in packing boxes of my Books to send to Boston— Was up late at Night reading my father’s manuscript account of his voyage to Europe, on the Negotiation for Peace.

4. The Stage called at 7. this Morning, an hour earlier than I had expected— I was packing a Trunk— Sent George into Boston and my father took me after breakfast part of the way— I walk’d the rest of it, and got home about 11. O’Clock— I went with Mr: I. P. Davis, and looked at the house which he has to dispose of, upon Fort-Hill— But I found that it would not answer my purpose— This afternoon and Evening I read something, but did not write.

5. The Greatest part of this day I was employed upon the business of my lectures, and wrote the beginning of the nineteenth. Took the children to walk with me in the Mall— Received my Trunk, which came from Washington by water. Spent the Evening with Mrs: Adams & Caroline at Dr: Welsh’s.

6. I was abroad all this morning, upon domestic concerns which seemed to be indispensable.— Dined with D. Sargent, and a company of about twenty Gentlemen.— The two Sisters of his late wife, Betsey and Harriet Frazier were there; and his daughter, Mary Osborn I saw for the first time— The weather was inclement, and we sat at table, untill past 9. in the Evening, after which I called, with Quincy at Mr: Emerson’s, where there was the Club. Only Judge Davis and Dr: Dexter however were there.— The day was of course lost to my occupations.

7. The weather, as much as my business confined me the whole of this day to my house— Excepting for about an hour before dinner, when business, and the necessity for exercise carried me a walk into State-Street— I prepared an advertisement which I put into the Repertory, for to-morrow.— Besides writing as much as I lay down for my task of my proper work, I wrote this Evening a letter, long due to Mr: Hopkinson of Philadelphia.— Si Sic Omnia.

div.p: 8. A severe cold, with a sore throat, and a rainy morning prevented me from going to Cambridge, at the usual hour to deliver my lecture— But I went in the Stage at 12. O’Clock, after calling upon Mr: Shaw— I sat about an hour with Dr: Waterhouse, and at 2. attended the declamation— There were eleven Speakers, which has been unexampled as yet during the present term— I walk’d home; and in the Evening attended at the chamber of the Society for the study of natural philosophy; but found only Dr: Gorham there.

9. We have had a series of foul weather almost uninterrupted for this fortnight— I was confined by it at home the greatest part of the day— Wrote a little— John Smith went out this Evening with Louisa to Quincy.

10. I took Mr: Brooks’s pew at the first Church for the Season, untill November— Heard Mr: Emerson the whole day; with my children— Caroline went in the afternoon. Walk in the Evening with Mrs: Adams, who after returning home, was extremely ill most of the Night with a sick head-ache.

11. Mrs: Adams continued very unwell the whole of this day; but rode out in the afternoon— I spent the day principally at home and wrote a little— My brother and his wife were in town but I did not see them— Walk in the Evening with George, over Beacon-Hill; saw the numerous new houses on the North side of the Hill; which have quite metamorphosed the appearance of that part of the Town— There was an initial Caucus at Vila’s this Evening to which I was invited, but which I did not attend—It respected the choice of Representatives for this town. About 10 this Evening there came to me a Committee of three members, Mr: J. Phillips, Mr: Bell, and Mr: Sumner, to request me to attend the general Caucus to-morrow Evening, and make a Speech—which I very explicitly declined— And I frankly told them I never had made a Speech at Caucus or at Town-meeting and did not think I ever should— For the present a sufficient excuse for me was that I had been so shortly an inhabitant of the Town, as scarcely to be qualified to vote; but to prevent any future applications of the same kind, which coming from my friends it would always be painful to refuse, I thought it best to give an Answer, once for all— They desired me to think further of it, which I agreed to; but told them I did not expect further reflection would change my determination— Miss Dexter spent the Evening here with Caroline.

12. After spending the whole morning in occupations of little moment, I walk’d in the Evening with both my children. Sent my letter and pamphlet to Mr: Hopkinson— Wrote a little of the first sketch of my lecture— My youngest boy has a very troublesome cough.

13. The Representatives for the town, were elected, but instead of 5000 votes there were less than 900 returned. No opposition to the list of the last year, being 27. members. I was not well, having been much disturbed in my rest last Night, by the illness of my child— Attended the club however this Evening, at Mr: E. Gray’s. I was so drowsy and feverish during the greatest part of the day, that I found it almost impossible to read; and wrote very little.

14. Employed as much of the day in writing and reading as I could command. Mr: Gallison spoke to me again this day; wishing to place his Son with me as a Student at Law— Walk’d in the Mall in the Evening with Caroline, and took George with us.

15. Rain the greatest part of the day— I walk’d to Cambridge, and at l0. in the morning delivered my sixteenth Lecture, with which I close the subject of Invention.— Spend a couple of hours in the Library, and read the remainder of Leland’s controversy against Warburton on the subject of Eloquence— Called upon President Webber and Mr: Ware; neither of whom could engage to dine with me, on the day of the Academy’s meeting— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s— Declamation at 2. The last of the Quarter; and very indifferent— Walk’d home; and in the Evening took a short walk with my boys in the Mall. Complaints, concerning some of my tenants, below Mr: Gardner.

16. My Tenants against whom the complaints were made this day left my house— My Mother came into Boston this morning with Louisa Smith, and this afternoon, I went with her out to Quincy; took John with me— As Gurley’s lease also is now expiring I called on A. Dexter who has his assignment, respecting the delivery of my keys; but he was not to be found— Wrote but little.

17. Heard a Mr: Noyes, preach upon subjects which I did not understand, and of which he appeared to know as little— Employed the remainder of the day in packing up another box of my books to send into Boston. Transplanted also some young Nectarines; though almost all my labours of the three last years have been rooted up, both at my father’s, and at my own place.— Evening with Boylston Adams at my brother’s Office.

18. I came into Boston this morning in the Stage, and my brother came in afterwards in the Stage, and brought with him John Smith and my John. Mrs: Parker, who has hitherto kept the school to which my children have gone, this day moved away to a distant part of the town— I went to Mr: Webb, and prevailed upon him to let George come to him the whole day— So that I shall take him away from the woman’s school altogether— He is to begin upon English grammar with an abridgement of L. Murray’s Grammar.— I called at Andrew Dexter’s Office to get the keys of my house in Court-Street; of which the lease to Gurley has now expired; but I could not find him.— The house also just below me is now upon my hands, the person who had made application to Mr: Davis having taken another house— I wrote very little of my lecture, but I wrote and copied one or two letters.

19. I put my youngest child John to school at a Mrs: M’Clincher’s, who keeps her school a few doors below me in Frog-Lane— I was still unable to find Mr: Dexter, or any person acting for him; and unable to do any business; I gave as much time as I can now ever command in one day to my regular studies but was able to write but very little— I began the first draught of my twentieth lecture— But the difficulties of my subject grow upon me instead of diminishing, and the cares of a family multiplied in the minutest and most miserable details of drudgery scarcely leave me the due command of my patience or of my temper.— I walk’d out with my boys this Evening, but we were soon driven home by the rain.

20. After a day as busily employed as I could make it, and walking with my boys in the Mall, I spent the Evening with the Club at Dr: Howard’s— I had prepared an advertisement for my house lately vacated, to be let, and carried it to the Office of the commercial Gazette; but Mr: Gurney made application for it this afternoon, in consequence of which I countermanded the advertisement for the present— I am still unable to find any person authorized to act for Mr: Andrew Dexter, and of course to make the arrangements for my house, and Office in Court-Street.

21. We were disturbed during the greater part of the Night by the illness of our child John, who has a very troublesome cold, and was very restless— The loss of my repose untill day-break, occasioned me to keep my bed later in the morning, and thus broke in upon my hours of business and study— Then through the day I wrote and read as much as I could; and spent the Evening; after a walk with George, at Dr: Welsh’s— I was obliged to leave John at home; and we had kept him from school— Mr: Otis and his family were also at Dr: Welsh’s.

22. A Rainy morning. It was again very late before I rose, because I had again been kept in constant disquiet, almost the whole Night through. Mr: Gurney came and looked over the house—proposes to give his answer to-morrow. Mr: Faxon the father called with a proposal to hire some land of mine at Quincy, concerning which I referred him to my brother— In the Evening I went with Caroline Johnson, and John Smith to a Ball at Mr: Stephen Higginson junrs: given to a Miss Fairlie, a young lady, on a visit here from New-York— It was a dull Evening to me— I knew but a small part of the company; and was reduced to the necessity of playing cards to pass the time— The ball and supper were very splendid. I came home about Midnight, and my companions an hour later

23. Load of Books and Cow from Quincy arrived this morning— Mr: Gurney came and engaged the house— To move in on Monday— Mr: I. P. Davis is going to Philadelphia, expecting to be married, and to be absent about 2. Months. I drew Notes to be discounted at the Banks, at the times when my present notes to him will become payable; and he endorsed them— I keep the notes to be delivered at the proper time— My Sister Smith with her daughter Caroline, came into town to spend some time with us— My brother Charles’s daughter Susan also came with her, but returned to Quincy with Mr: Shaw, this Evening— Shaw took out also my two boys with him— They are gone to pass the Election week at my father’s. It is a week of vacation at all the Schools in Boston; and began at Mr: Webb’s school this day.— I was not well this day, and the unpacking of my books and other occupations of a like nature engrossed all my time— I wrote not a line of my lectures— Walk in the Mall, and in the Evening played chess with my Sister.

24. Had for the first time this week a quiet Night. The day was stormy; with plentiful rain— Heard Mr: Emerson, whose Audience in the morning was very thin; and not very large in the afternoon— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 101. 102.

25. I was employed the whole day in such occupations as essentially interfered with my principal duty; and wrote nothing. The morning I was abroad— Called again upon A. Dexter, without better success than before. Walk’d about an hour in the Mall, this Evening

26. Annual meeting of the Academy for the choice of their Officers— Those of the last year were rechosen excepting that Presidt: Webber was elected Vice-President, instead of Judge Dana who declined that Office. There was very little other business done, and few Communications read— The meeting was dissolved about half past 2. O’Clock.— We had Company at dinner. My father and Dr: Tufts—Mr: J. S. J. Gardiner and Dr: Kirkland, Mr: Jackson the Treasurer, Mr: S. Dexter—Dr: Warren and Dr: Waterhouse—Mr: Boylston and Mr: Quincy— Mr: Shaw came in after dinner— My brother’s wife, and her brother—W. Smith and his Sister’s—Dr: Welsh and Charlotte were here in the Evening— This morning a party of nearly two hundred young Men went out to escort Governor Strong into Town; where he comes for the last time in his official capacity— Mr: Sullivan is to be the Governor, for the ensuing year— John Smith went with my father to Quincy this afternoon.

27. Annual Election day— John Smith returned to town this Morning, and my brother came in with him— They brought home George, but left John to pass the remainder of the week at Quincy— I called at Mr: Hall’s Office; and at Mr A. Dexter’s whom I still could not find— Took George with me to see the procession of Members from the State-House, and to hear the Election Sermon which was delivered by Mr: Bentley of Salem— After losing a great part of the afternoon, as well as of the morning, I finally wrote perhaps half a page— Spent the Evening with all the family at Mr: W. Smith’s.

28. Confined the greatest part of this day to the house, but it was engross’d by the labour of sorting and fixing up books, of the load which came last from Quincy. The work is still not half done. After a walk in the Mall with George, I pass’d the Evening, with the Ladies at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— As the time approaches when I must recommence my lectures, I feel the pressure of my business weighing more and more heavily upon me, and yet waste my time in a most unjustifiable manner.

29. The new Governor of the State Mr: Sullivan, and the Lieutenant Governor, Mr: Lincoln were this day sworn into office— The number of votes for Governor was upwards of 80,000—for the last three Elections they have encreased about 5000 every time— Mr: Strong though he loses the choice, had about 3000 votes more than last year— I wrote upon my lecture this forenoon— Mr: A. Dexter’s Clerk, Mr: Edwards finally called at my house, and settled the affair of my lease to Gurley. In the afternoon I went with all the family to the Chapel Church, and heard Mr: L. Richardson’s Address to the Charitable Fire Society— The Music was very good; though Mrs: Oldmixon’s performance was refined beyond the temper of our public taste.— Spent the Evening with the family at Dr: Welsh’s— Mr: S. A. Otis with his family & Mr: W. Smith’s children were there. We also took George with us.

30. After finishing a paper for Mrs: Hall of Barbadoes, I called upon Mr: S. Dexter, and examined the State of the papers, with him— It is very questionable whether any thing can yet be done in the case— I was however so much occupied with this business the whole day, that I found not half an hour to write upon my lectures. My father and Mother came into Town— The Trustees of the agricultural Society met at Dr: Kirkland’s— I pass’d my time not idly; though in occupations perhaps of not much utility— Walk’d this Evening in the Mall.— Dr: Waterhouse called.

31. Cold and Rainy day— Heard Mr: Emerson— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 103. 104. And wrote something for my lectures. Walk’d in the Mall this Evening, so that I could not be altogether dissatisfied with my days employment.

Day. Since my return from Washington, and the renewal of my residence in Boston the consumption of my time has been a subject of great distress to my mind— One of its greatest evils has been disorder. I have no regular hour of rising. My wife, and youngest child have been ill almost incessantly since my return, and their illness has been most troublesome in the Night— I have never had the benefit of rest so much as two Nights in the week.— When kept up half the night or more, I have always had the weakness to keep my bed an hour or two later in the Morning, so that my rising hour varies with the utmost irregularity, from 5 to 9. When I have any time before breakfast, I read 4 Chapters of the Bible, and hear George read in Dufief’s grammar— Breakfast usually from 9 to 10.— Then my private business—the meanest minutia of household affairs, and my lectures employ me alternately untill 1. when I walk to one of the Insurance Offices—return about 2. and after dinner untill dark am again distracted by the same variety of petty business— I then walk about an hour—which brings us nearly to 9 in the Evening— Sup—and retire between 10 and 11. at Night. At the commencement of the Evening, when I can I hear George read again, in Berquin’s Ami des Enfans— The collecting together my furniture and books has also contributed to engross much of my time; and is not yet completed— On the whole this month has given me no more self-satisfaction than the last; and I must still rest upon futurity my hopes of Amendment.
